OTW is an intervention program that seeks out veterans experiencing early warning signs of psychological injuries and provides preventative and early mental health treatment. Counseling through Outside the Wire includes: substance abuse intervention, parenting skills intervention, anger management strategies, coping and problem-solving skills, and therapy for Post-Traumatic Stress (including Cognitive Behavior Therapy and Exposure Therapy).The OTW clinical team consists of licensed psychologist and social works who are specially trained in military life, culture, and unique issues that veterans and their families face while transitioning to civilian life. Some of our clinicians are veterans themselves. In addition, OTW offers a training program to doctoral level psychology trainees and MSW students who specialize in military social work, expanding the network of mental health professionals with training in military and veteran issues.Through strong partnerships with colleges throughout southern California, OTW brings comprehensive mental health services to veterans - both students and non-students - right in their own communities.Since 1993, U.S.VETS has been a leader in helping homeless veterans overcome their challenges and get their lives back on track. With Outside the Wire, U.S.VETS helps post-9/11 veterans transition successfully to civilian life, long before they ever become homeless.

Description: Peer Collective provides access to mental health support through our peer counselors who are highly skilled and empathetic listeners making emotional support affordable and available at the push of a button. Services provided: - Peer counseling. Our counselors have an incredible diversity of backgrounds and life experience, they also approach coping with and overcoming challenges in diverse ways. Some focus on listening and validating, while others focus on reframing situations or solving problems. There is no one-size-fits-all approach to life. The core of peer counseling is that the relationship is based on shared experience, rather than diagnosing and treating a mental illness. We’re open and transparent about the challenges we’ve faced, so you can find someone who can relate. We offer 30-minute online counseling sessions for just $14. This allows us to pay our counselors a living wage, while making emotional support as easy to access as possible. Sessions happen over Zoom, so they can be audio or video. Peer Collective counselors have passed our rigorous screening and demonstrate exceptional empathy, warmth, and understanding, but are not licensed therapists and don’t diagnose or treat mental disorders. Instead, their job is to support you in whatever way you want to be supported.
